Preclassical Period || Milinda-pañha
2.3 Milinda-pañha

Milinda-pañha (Questions of King Milinda),
unlike the Kathā-vatthu which comprises an argumentative
exchange adhering to identifiable patterns, comprises a dialogue
between the Greek Bactrian king, Menander (Pāli: Milinda), and an
otherwise unknown Buddhist monk, Nāgasena (von Hinüber,
1996, III.4). The text is an exposition of Buddhist doctrine and
practice, cast in terms of questions put by King Milinda to the monk
Nāgasena and the latter’s answers. Though there is some
argumentation, for the most part, the text is expository, where the
exposition is done almost entirely through analogy, sometimes very
elaborate ones. For example, Book 5, entitled ‘the problem of
inference’, which has almost nothing to do with inference, sets
out an elaborate analogy between a great city and its various parts,
on the one hand, and the Buddha’s teaching and its various
parts, on the other. The pretext for this expository analogy is an
argument put to Nāgasena by King Milinda. King Milinda asks
whether Nāgasena or his teachers has seen the Buddha.
Nāgasena replies that neither he nor his teachers has. King
Milinda concludes, then, that the Buddha did not exist. Nāgasena
replies by making a similar argument whose premiss King Milinda
accepts but whose conclusion he rejects. King Milinda admits that
neither he nor those who have taught him has seen the founders of his
kingly lineage, yet he believes that the founder of his lineage
existed. (Bk. 5, sec. 2) Then King Milinda replies that he has
evidence for belief in the existence of a founder, the existence of
the royal insignia. Nāgasena then counters that he too has
evidence for the existence of the Buddha, namely, his various
doctrines, metaphorically the royal insignia of the Buddha. (Bk. 5,
sec. 3) In short, just as one infers the existence of a founder of a
lineage from the legacy of his royal insignia, so one infers the
existence of the Buddha from the legacy of his teachings.
Nāgasena then turns to a similar argument which serves as a
pretext to elaborate various aspects of the Buddha’s teaching:
just as one can infer from a well planned city the fact that it had a
designer, so one can infer from the well ordered doctrines of the
Buddha that the Buddha existed. Over the ensuing 20 sections,
Nāgasena first enumerates various features of the city and then
elaborates on aspects of Buddhist doctrines put in correspondence with
them. The final section ends with eight arguments, each paired through
analogy with an argument pertaining to features of Buddhist thought
and the existence or features of the Buddha. (1) From the greatness of
the city one infers the greatness of the architect. (2) From the
greatness of the waves, one infers the greatness of the ocean; (3)
From seeing the peaks of mountains from afar, one infers the height of
the mountains; (4) From the greatness of an elephant’s
footprint, one infers the size of the elephant; (5) From seeing
creatures crouching in fear, one infers that a lion has roared; (6)
From the luxuriance of the vegetation, one infers the ampleness of
rainfall; (7) From the marshiness of the earth, one infers the excess
of rainfall; (8) From the scent in the air, one infers that flowers
are in bloom. Each of these arguments has the form of what is dubbed
to be the pramāṇa, the means of epistemic
cognition, known as anumāna, or inference.

One important principle of logic is presupposed in the dialogue: the
principle of non-contradiction. It is presupposed in a variety of
places throughout the text, but it is particularly in evidence in Book
4, which is entitled ‘Solving the dilemmas’. The book
consists of dilemmas put to Nāgasena by King Milinda. Many of
them are pairs of apparently inconsistent statements or practices
inconsistent with doctrine. They correspond to the following schema in
propositional logic: \(p \land q,\) \(p \to \neg q,\) \(q \to \neg
p.\) One particularly clear instance occurs in section 6 of Chapter 2.
There King Milinda says:


If the Blessed one, Nāgasena, really said that all men tremble at
punishment and all are afraid of death, then the statement that the
Arhat has passed beyond fear must be false. But if that last statement
is really by him, then the other must be false. (T. W. Rhys Davids
1980.)


Nāgasena’s response is to point out, in effect, that the
intended meaning is different from the literal meaning. He gives
several examples of sentences in which the word all occurs but where
all in not intended to include everyone in what we today call the
domain of discourse. He points out (in section 8) that a king might
tell his four ministers that all must pay taxes, but the king does not
intend that the ministers are included by all, ministers being free
from the burden of taxation. In another example (section 9), he points
out that a village headman may tell the village crier to bring
together all the villagers, but in fact, what he intends is that only
all the heads of households gather.
